title: Opposite Angles in a Parallelogram
solution_hints: Opposite angles in a parallelogram are equal.

title: Diagonal in a Rectangle
problem_text: Rectangle PQRS has diagonal PR drawn. If ∠QPR = 42°, find ∠PRQ.
solution_hints: Use angle sum of a triangle.
common_pitfalls: Using 42° + 42° instead of 90° + 42° when summing angles.
verified_methodology: Step 1 – Triangle PQR is right-angled at Q (90°).
Step 2 – Sum of angles in ΔPQR: 90° + 42° + ∠PRQ = 180°.

title: Adjacent Angles in a Rhombus
solution_hints: Adjacent angles of any parallelogram (and thus a rhombus) are supplementary.
common_pitfalls: Assuming all angles are equal (only true for a square).

title: Base Angles in an Isosceles Trapezium
problem_text: Isosceles trapezium ABCD has AB ∥ CD and AD = BC. If ∠ABC = 65°, find ∠BAD.
solution_hints: Base angles on the same (parallel) base of an isosceles trapezium are equal.
verified_methodology: Step 1 – For base AB, the base angles are ∠ABC and ∠BAD.
Step 2 – These angles are equal in an isosceles trapezium.

title: Diagonal in a Square
problem_text: Square ABCD has diagonal AC drawn. Find ∠ACB.
solution_hints: The diagonal of a square creates two congruent isosceles right triangles.
common_pitfalls: Answering 90° (the square’s corner) instead of the triangle’s angle.
verified_methodology: Step 1 – ΔABC is right-angled at B with AB = BC.
Step 2 – Base angles in an isosceles right triangle are 45°.

title: Angle Sum in a Triangle
solution_hints: Use the angle-sum property of a triangle (180°).

title: Isosceles Triangle within the Strand
problem_text: Isosceles ΔPQR has PQ = PR and ∠QPR = 34°. Find ∠PQR.
solution_hints: Base angles in an isosceles triangle are equal.
common_pitfalls: Dividing the remaining angle by 3 instead of 2.
verified_methodology: Step 1 – Sum of the two base angles = 180° − 34° = 146°.

title: Opposite Angles in a Parallelogram (II)
solution_hints: Consecutive angles in a parallelogram are supplementary.
